Conrad Zhang a ⁎ a Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian Liaoning 116023 China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China c School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Selective hydrogenation of carbonyl groups in biobased chemicals to alcohols is crucial to the economics of broadly sustainable product portfolios. Furfuryl alcohol (FOL), the most prominent chemical of hemicellulose, has been produced by furfural (FAL) hydrogenation over heterogeneous catalysts. In this work, we show the outstanding activity, selectivity, and stability of supported bimetallic PtCo nanoparticle (np) synthesized from a pre-made stock solution of zero valent atomic Pt precursor and Co2(CO)8. With only 0.5 wt% Pt on TiO2, the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst exhibits TOF of 14,023 h−1 at 30 °C with > 99.9% FOL selectivity. The stability of the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst is verified by the steady performance in reuses at both moderate and full conversions. The oxyphilic Coδ+ in the PtCo nanoparticles induces nucleophilic chemisorption of -CO, resulting in deeply polarized CO bond. DFT calculated FAL adsorption energies on np-Pt and np-PtCo are − 0.22 eV and − 0.74 eV, respectively. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Zero-valent Pt atom precursor PtCo bimetallic catalyst Selective activation Furfural hydrogenation Furfuryl alcohol 1 Introduction Lignocellulosic biomass is the most abundant renewable carbon resource to produce biofuels and biochemicals [1–4]. Carbonyls are one of the prevailing functional groups of most biobased platform chemicals derived from carbohydrates. Selective hydrogenation of the carbonyl groups to alcohols is crucially important to the economics of broadly sustainable product portfolios from biomass. Furfural (FAL), one of the most promising bio-based platform molecules derived from arabinose and xylose as components of hemicellulose, can be hydrogenated to many higher value-added fine chemicals including furfuryl alcohol (FOL), 2-methylfuran (2-MF), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL), furan, 2-methyterahydrofuran (2-MTHF) and various diols [5–7]. Especially, FOL has played a pivotal role in the syntheses and applications of C5 sugar derived chemicals from hemicellulose, such as foundry resins, biofuels, and fine chemical products [8–11]. However, the complex groups (CC, CO, C-O-C, etc.) in furfural and furfural oligomerization make it catalytically demanding to maintain high furfural hydrogenation rate, high furfuryl alcohol selectivity, and most importantly long operational catalyst life in extended uses [12,13]. Catalytic processes have been extensively studied to increase biomass utilization efficiency and the selective activation of CO bond in furfural; producing FOL is of great interest and has received tenacious attention [4,13–15]. Cu-Cr (CuCr2O4) catalyst has been commercially used to produce FOL at around 180 ℃ under 7–10 MPa in a batch process [16]. However, the toxicity associated with the use of Cr and harsh conditions for the reaction are the main drawbacks of this process [17]. Although Cr-free transition metal catalysts such as Cu/SiO2, NiBi/Al2O3, Co/SBA-15 and others have been developed, most of the them still require elevated pressure (> 7 MPa) and temperature (>100 ℃) to achieve high FAL conversion [18–21]. Unfortunately, the use of high temperature, on the one hand, usually causes side reactions which raise the cost of separating and purifying FOL from by-products, in addition to generating waste by-product. On the other hand, catalyst deactivation becomes serious due to oligomerization of FAL on catalyst surface, as well metal particle sintering [22–24]. Furthermore, very high metal loadings are essential to obtain acceptable conversions even at high reaction temperatures. Poor catalyst stability due to fouling by oligomer formation and due to metal particles sintering inevitably increased the operational cost of the processes due to the need to frequently discharge the catalyst, resulting in the interruption of the production processes, in addition to the cost of reclaiming the metals from the deactivated catalysts or even as a better option the cost of regenerating the used catalysts. Supported noble metal catalysts provide a potential alternative for their high activity at much lower operating temperature which may alleviate the catalyst deactivation issue. The prospects of prolonged catalyst lifetime and much reduced frequency of interruption to the production process may compensate the higher cost of the supported noble metal catalysts, although there remains the challenge of reducing the catalyst cost by minimizing the supported noble metal loading on such catalysts. Recently, Pt-based and Pd-based noble metals catalysts have been studied for selective FAL hydrogenation for their high performance at relatively mild conditions [25–28]. For example, a 5%Pt/g-C3N4 catalyst showed > 99% conversion of FAL with > 99% FOL selectivity at 100 °C and 1 MPa H2, having a TOF of 75 h−1 [29]. In another example, a 3 wt% Pt/HT catalyst was reported to offer > 99.9% conversion of FAL with > 99% selectivity to FOL at 30 °C under 1.5 MPa H2 pressure, at TOF of 204.6 h−1 [30]. Usually, bimetallic catalysts showed superior catalytic performance to their monometallic counterparts in catalytic hydrogenations [10,13,31,32]. For examples, a 5%Pd-5%Cu/MgO bimetallic catalyst exhibited higher than 98% FOL selectivity at complete FAL conversion under 110 °C and 0.6 MPa H2 pressure, and the performance of the bimetallic 5%Pd-5%Cu catalyst was improved over the monometallic 5%Pd catalyst [33]. Compared to monometallic Pt/CeO2, Fe additive modified 2%Pt3Fe/CeO2 catalyst was proposed to promote H2 dissociation for the accelerated FAL hydrogenation, achieving > 99% selectivity to FOL at 100 °C under 2 MPa H2 pressure and the specific reaction rate was around 1500 h−1 [13]. Although the bimetallic catalysts have shown exciting results for selective hydrogenation of FAL to FOL, the noble metal loadings of the reported catalysts were typically higher than 2% to obtain good activity [34]. To make the noble metal catalysts economically competitive, developing a method of catalyst preparation to achieve high activity and stability with low noble metal loading is an important strategy, but it is conceivably challenging to achieve the catalyst performance objectives. For this purpose, it would be desirable to have the noble metal particles narrowly distributed in small size range and highly dispersed on support surfaces. Developing bimetallic catalysts containing an inexpensive transition metal to achieve synergistic effect offers a supplementary strategy in further reducing the noble metal loading. We recently reported the successful synthesis of bi/trinuclear Pt1&2Cu clusters, which showed superior catalysis performance than monometallic Pt1(0) @PDMS-PEG at ultra-low catalyst/reactant mol ratio [35,36]. In this work, we use a simpler Pt 1 0 stock solution composed of mononuclear precursor (C2H5OC2H4OC2H5)Pt1(0)(HCl)2 in ethanol/glycol ether/H2O, by adding a Co precursor, to directly prepare a stock solution of bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles [37]. The synthesized bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles on anatase TiO2 (np-PtCo/TiO2) using the stock solution as the metal precursor showed excellent performance for selective hydrogenation of FAL to FOL in comparison to monometallic Pt nanoparticles. We further compared the differences between the adsorption modes of FAL on np-Pt/TiO2 and on np-PtCo/TiO2 to reveal the dramatic role of Co in the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst for the markedly reduced apparent active energy. Importantly, the stability of the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst is demonstrated by multiple test matrices and the roles of Co on the stability of the bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles and on the reaction mechanism are studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals TiO2 (99.8%) (Anatase, 5–10 nm), ethylene glycol diethyl ether (99%) and cobalt carbonyl (98%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Iso-propanol (99.9%) was purchased from Kermel Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Chloroplatinic acid, ethanol (99.8%), furfural (99.0%), 1–4 dioxane (99.5%), hydrochloric acid (36.0–38.0%) and NaOH (99%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Ultrapure water purified by Milli-Q Advantage A 10 was used. H2 (99.999%) was obtained from JF-Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation method 2.2.1 Preparation of Pt1, Pt1Co and Co solutions The Pt 1 0 stock solution (0.58 mM) was prepared by reducing H2PtCl6 with ethanol in glycol ether.37 Briefly, the mixture of H2PtCl6, ethanol, ethylene glycol diethyl ether (EGDE) and ultrapure water was heated to 82 ℃ for 2 h and then cooled to room temperature. The Pt1Co stock solution was prepared by adding Co2(CO)8 into the Pt1 solution. 15 mg of Co2(CO)8 was put into a three-necked round-bottom flask in the glove box and transferred to a Schlenk line. 150 ml of Pt1 solution was injected into the flask containing Co2(CO)8 under continuous stirring. Then the mixture was refluxed at 60 ℃ for 3 h under nitrogen. The Co solution for reference purpose was prepared by adding Co2(CO)8 into the mixture of ethanol, EGDE, ultrapure water and hydrochloric acid. Then the mixture was also refluxed at 60 ℃ for 3 h under nitrogen. Hydrochloric acid is used in an amount to reach the same pH as the Pt1 solution. 2.2.2 Preparation of Pt1/TiO2 and Pt1Co/TiO2 samples An anatase TiO2 was used and evaluated in full detail as the Pt catalyst support in this work. Similar preparation and preliminary catalytic assessment were made with SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 supports only for initial screening purpose. We first prepared 0.5 wt% Pt1/TiO2 by wet impregnation of Pt1 solution [37]. Typically, 1.131 g TiO2 targeted for the 0.5 wt% Pt loading was added to 100 ml Pt1 solution (Pt conc. 0.58 mM). After stirring for 12 h, the solvent was evaporated, and the sample was dried under vacuum at 40 °C. Similarly, the atomically dispersed 0.5 wt% Pt1Co/TiO2 (0.5 wt% Pt loading) sample was synthesized by using Pt1Co solution following the similar procedure as that in the preparation of Pt1/TiO2. 2.2.3 Preparation of np-Pt/TiO2, np-PtCo/TiO2, Co/TiO2 and np-Pt/TiO2-g catalysts The np-Pt/TiO2 catalyst (Pt nanoparticles supported on TiO2) was synthesized by pretreating Pt1/TiO2 in a quartz tube with 4 ml iso-propanol (IPA) under 1 MPa H2 (99.99%) at 60 ℃ unless specified for 2 h before cooling to room temperature. After the H2 treatment, the sample was filtrated (washed by ethanol), and dried under vacuum at 40 ℃ before use. Unless specified, the np-Pt/TiO2 stands for samples prepared in IPA solution. The preparation procedure of np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst was similar to that of np-Pt/TiO2 catalyst by treating Pt1Co/TiO2 under H2 in IPA solution. In the preparation of Co/TiO2 catalyst, a similar procedure was used from the Co solution with anatase TiO2 support. The loading of Co in Co/TiO2 is consistent with that in np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst. Another preparation method without the solution was also used by treating the Pt1/TiO2 in a quartz tube under 10% H2/Ar (40 ml/min) with a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min to 100 ℃ and held at this temperature for 2 h before cooling to room temperature. This catalyst is named np-Pt/TiO2-g where g stands for gas phase H2 pretreatment. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The metal loading of the catalysts was determined by a PerkinElmer Optima 8000 inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). The Pt loading was 0.50 wt% in both np-Pt/TiO2 and np-PtCo/TiO2. The Co loading was 0.11%, corresponding to a Co/Pt atomic ratio of 0.7. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy was applied to differentiate Pt single atoms from Pt nanoparticles. Typically, DRIFT spectra during 5% CO/He adsorption on the samples were collected at 25 ℃ with a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 spectrometer equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride detector at a resolution of 4 cm−1 using 64 scans. The sample was evacuated at 25 °C for 2 h or purged in Ar for 1 h before the DRIFT measurements. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was performed on a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope operated at 120 kV at a resolution of 0.23 nm. The atomic resolution analysis and elemental mapping were performed on a JEM-ARM200F thermal-field emission microscope with a probe spherical aberration (Cs) corrector working at 200 kv. For high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image, a convergence angle of ~23 mrad and a collection angle range of 68–174 mrad were adapted for the incoherent atomic number imaging. Before microscopy examination, the samples were dry dispersed onto a copper grid coated with a thin holey carbon film. The elemental composition as well as distribution were studied on a microscope equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray (EDS) analyzer (EX-230 100 m2 detector) including energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) analysis. X-ray diffractograms (XRD) were obtained using PANalytical X′Pert Powder X-ray diffractometer with a graphite monochromator and Cu Kα radiation, operating at 40 kV and scanning 2θ from 5° to 80° with a step of 0.013°. The binding energy (B.E.) of the catalyst was determined by XPS on an ESCALAB250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with contaminated C as the internal standard (C1s = 284.6 eV). As the signal sensitivities of Co and Pt in XPS measurement were poor when Pt loading is at 0.5 wt% at the Co/Pt mol ratio of 0.7, we used the 2 wt% Pt catalyst at the same Co/Pt ratio only for XPS measurements of Pt and Co binding energies for better signal intensity. 2.4 Catalytic evaluations Furfural (FAL) hydrogenation was carried out in a 15 ml stainless-steel autoclave with quartz tube liner. In a typical reaction, 50 mg of FAL was transferred into a quartz tube containing 20 mg of catalyst and 4 ml of IPA. The reactor was initially flushed with N2 and then flushed and filled with H2 to 1 MPa at room temperature. The reaction was maintained at 30 ℃ under agitation (350 rpm) for 5 h to ensure full conversion of FAL. After termination of the reaction, 1,4-dioxane was added to the reactor as the internal standard reference for quantitative analysis. The products were analyzed by gas chromatography (Agilent Technologies 7890; column-DB-1, 60 m × 0.32 mm × 0.5 µm) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) using a program: 50–150 ℃ at 15 ℃/min ramp rate, 150–280 ℃ at 25 ℃/min ramp rate. The products were identified by GC-MS (Agilent Technologies 7890; column-HP-5MS, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.5 µm). The conversion, product selectivity, turn over frequency (TOF) and specific reaction rate were calculated using following equations: (1) Conversion ( % ) = Initial mole of FAL − Final mole of FAL Initial mole of FAL × 100 % (2) Selectivity % = Mole of desired product formed Initial mole of FAL − Final mole of FAL × 100 % (3) TOF ( h − 1 ) = mole of FAL converted mole of metal active sites × time (4) Specific reaction rate ( h − 1 ) = mole of FAL converted mole of Pt × time In Eq. (3), the mole of metal active sites was determined by the classical static CO chemisorption and the stoichiometry between the amount of adsorbed CO and metal atom was assumed to be 1:1. 2.5 DFT calculations Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were applied under the Vienna Ab Simulation Package (VASP) with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhoff (PBE) functional and the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [38]. The Pt (111) surface was modeled with three atomic layers and p (4 ×4) super cell. Co atom was doped in Pt (111) with 0.7 Co/Pt molar ratio and the vacuum layer was set as 15 Å between the periodic slabs. The bottom one layer was fixed. The cutoff energy was 400 eV, and k point of 3 × 3 × 1 in Monkhorst-Pack grid was used. The forces change between two steps was smaller than 0.02 eV·Å–1. The adsorption energy (Ead) of FAL was calculated according to the equation: (5) E ad = E total − E surface + E adsorbate where E total is the energy of adsorption state; E surface is the energy of the clean slab, and E adsorbate is the energy of the free adsorbate in gas phase. 2.6 The reuse of np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst After each run, the catalyst was separated by filtration, washed with ethanol, followed by evacuation at room temperature for 2 h. The catalyst was reused in five consecutive tests after recycle without any reactivation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Pt1/TiO2 and Pt1Co/TiO2 The Pt1/TiO2 sample shows the same atomically dispersed features as in our previous work, as confirmed by the in situ DRIFT spectra of adsorbed CO at 2099 cm−1 (Fig. S1a) and by TEM image (Fig. S1b) of this sample [36,37]. We further characterized the Pt1Co/TiO2 sample. The DRIFT spectra of Pt1Co/TiO2 ( Fig. 1a) display only one band at 2105 cm−1 which may be attributed to CO adsorbed on Pt1, indicating the absence of Pt nanoparticles. The HAADF-STEM image of Pt1Co/TiO2 (Fig. 1b) sample further shows the mononuclear Pt on TiO2 without Pt clusters or nanoparticles. As Co and Ti are relatively close in their atomic numbers, the contrast between Co and Ti atoms is expected to be small for TEM to differentiate Co from Ti [39]. The oxidation states of Pt and Co in Pt1Co/TiO2 were studied by XPS. The binding energy of Pt 4f7/2 at 71.5 eV (Fig. 1c) is only slightly higher than that of bulk Pt metal at 71.2 eV, indicating a reduced state of Pt in the Pt1Co/TiO2 sample [40,41]. What’s more, the peak at 781.3 eV with shake-up satellite peaks 786.2 eV of Co 2p3/2 (Fig. 1d) shows the presence of Co2+ in the Pt1Co/TiO2 catalyst [42,43]. The Co2+ may be formed by oxidation due to the existing HCl ligands associated with the (C2H5OC2H4OC2H5)Pt1(0)(HCl)2 precursor of Pt 1 0 when the Co precursor Co2(CO)8 was added to the Pt 1 0 precursor solution. 3.1.2 Monometallic Pt and bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles on TiO2 The anatase TiO2 supported monometallic Pt and bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles (np-Pt/TiO2 and np-PtCo/TiO2, respectively) were obtained by treating atomically dispersed Pt1/TiO2 and Pt1Co/TiO2 samples under H2 atmosphere as mentioned in 2.2.3 section. It is known that the Pt single atoms are thermodynamically unstable and tend to agglomerate under reaction conditions at elevated temperatures especially under reducing atmosphere like H2 [44,45]. It has been established that the Pt1 0complex precursor was protected by weakly coordinated H-Cl and ether [36,37]. The weak coordination environment may be expected to make Pt center even more sensitive to H2 at a relatively low temperature. On this basis, atomically dispersed Pt1/TiO2 was used as the pre-catalyst to synthesize monometallic Pt and bimetallic PtCo (by adding Co compound) nanoparticles over TiO2 under H2 atmosphere. The DRIFTs of CO chemisorption were applied to qualitatively analyze the states of Pt in monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. The DRIFT spectra of np-Pt/TiO2-g catalyst prepared in situ starting from Pt1/TiO2 under H2 atmosphere at different temperature are shown in Fig. 2a. With increasing temperature, the peak at 2098 cm−1 ascribed to CO absorbed on Pt1 (Fig. S1a) gradually disappeared, indicating that the Pt1 in Pt1/TiO2 was unstable under H2 atmosphere even at 60 ℃. At the same time, the peaks at 2052 and 1861 cm−1 assigned to linear and bridged CO adsorbed on Pt nanoparticles appeared. The results indicate that the H2 induced migration of Pt1 atoms over TiO2, forming Pt nanoparticles. Therefore, Pt1/TiO2 as atomically dispersed Pt pre-catalyst allows a convenient method for the controlled preparation of TiO2 supported Pt clusters or nanoparticles under mild conditions. We further obtained np-Pt/TiO2 catalyst at 60 ℃ under H2 in IPA solution. The DRIFT spectrum of CO adsorbed on the np-Pt/TiO2 (Fig. 2b) has similar DRIFT bands to that of np-Pt/TiO2-g, prepared by gaseous H2 treatment only at higher temperature. The band at 2099 cm−1 belonging to CO adsorbed on atomically dispersed Pt disappeared, while peaks at around 2060 and 1850 cm−1 corresponding to prevailing linear and bridging CO adsorbed on Pt nanoparticles, respectively, indicating the formation of nanoparticles at the expense of all the mononuclear Pt. For the bimetallic np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst, the CO FTIR absorption bands at 2063 and 1836 cm−1 (Fig. 2b) are also indicative of formation of Pt nanoparticles, in addition to the appearance of the band at 2010 cm−1. The band in the 2054–2001 cm−1 range is usually assigned to CO adsorbed on Co0 and Coδ+ (0 <δ < 1) sites [46,47]. Hence, we attribute the shoulder peak at 2010 cm−1 of np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst to CO absorbed on Coδ+ (0 <δ < 1). The observation that this band only appeared on the np-PtCo/TiO2, but not on np-Pt/TiO2 and np-Pt/TiO2-g suggested that Co on the np-PtCo/TiO2 was in reduced state in association with Pt nanoparticles. While XPS shows the presence of Co2+ on the Pt1Co/TiO2 pre-catalyst, the FT-IR spectra of adsorbed CO on the np-PtCo/TiO2 show reduced Co on the H2 treated catalyst. In addition, CO adsorption on Co2+ is expected to be very weak. The morphology of Pt nanoparticles was investigated by TEM. The np-Pt/TiO2-g catalyst obtained after treatment at 100 ℃ in H2 was used since the DRIFT spectrum of adsorbed CO showed that almost all mononuclear Pt disappeared under this condition. As shown in Fig. 3a, the lattice distance of 0.226 nm is assigned to Pt (111) plane, and Pt nanoparticles are well dispersed on TiO2 with mean particle size at 2.2 nm (Fig. 3b). Unlike the np-Pt/TiO2-g, the Pt of np-Pt/TiO2 obtained in IPA was severely agglomerated to particles in tens of nanometers (S1 in Fig. 4c) which was further supported by the EDX spectrum (Fig. 3d). Big Pt particles were also observed in other regions of the sample (Fig. S2). In general, excessive amount of stabilizers or surfactants have been used for the synthesis of metal colloids or nanoparticles in solutions [48,49]..It is not surprising that the Pt particles coalesce into big chunks in the absence of a stabilizer in solution. What’s more, the EDS spectrum (Fig. S3) of S2 area in Fig. 3c shows no Pt signal, indicating very few Pt particles in S2 area under the resolution of TEM. In contrast to monometallic Pt particles obtained in IPA, the bimetallic PtCo particles obtained in IPA under the same condition show high dispersion over TiO2 (Fig. 4a) and the mean particle size is at 2.8 nm (Fig. 4b). The measured lattice distance is 0.223 nm (Fig. 4a) that matches well with the Pt (111) plane, suggesting that the Co may be on the surface of Pt nanoparticles. In comparison, the origin for highly dispersed bimetallic PtCo particles over TiO2 could be attributed to the stabilization effect of Co which may be preferentially decorated at the low coordination sites of Pt nanoparticles [32]. Further, EDX line scanning and EELS were applied to study the microstructure of bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 4c and d, the compositional line profiles of Pt and Co cross two PtCo particles in Fig. 4c suggests the matched distributions of elemental Pt/Co. EELS (Fig. 4e) spectrum corresponding to area II of Fig. 4c, displays the peak of Co L-edge which further verified the coexistence of Co and Pt [50,51]. The XRD patterns of anatase TiO2 powder, np-Pt/TiO2 and np-PtCo/TiO2 catalysts are shown in (Fig. S4). The patterns of both np-Pt/TiO2 and np-PtCo/TiO2 are almost identical to that of anatase TiO2 support. The absence of supported metal peaks could be due to the small size of metal nanoparticles or low loading of Pt (~ 0.5 wt%) dispersed on TiO2. XPS was used to study the electronic properties of metals in monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. For np-Pt/TiO2 catalyst ( Fig. 5a), the peak for Pt 4f7/2 at binding energy of 70.3 eV is lower than that of bulk Pt metal (71.2 eV), indicating the Pt of np-Pt/TiO2 catalyst is in reduced state with an electron rich state [32,52,53]. The XPS spectrum of Co/TiO2 catalyst was collected at 0.6 wt% Co loading (Fig. S5). As expected, the binding energy of 781.1 eV for Co 2p3/2 shows that Co is in +2 valence state, indicating the Co2+ alone was not reduced under the catalyst preparation condition. In the XPS spectrum of np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 5b), the peak for Pt 4f7/2 at 70.74 eV also indicates the reduced state of Pt. The peak of Pt 4f7/2 at 70.4 eV in np-PtCo/TiO2 is slightly blue-shifted compared to that of np-Pt/TiO2 (70.3 eV), indicating the d-band center of bimetallic PtCo nanoparticle downshifted as reported by previous work [54]. However, repeated XPS analyses did not show sufficiently distinguishable signal intensity of Co 2p, likely due to the detection sensitivity of XPS at the low Co loading. 3.2 Catalytic performance and mechanistic study 3.2.1 Catalytic performance of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts The catalytic performances of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts for selective hydrogenation of FAL to FOL were evaluated. As shown in Fig. 6a, the FAL conversion over commercial anatase TiO2 support was 19%; only 2-(diisopropoxymethyl) furan (DPMF) was detected without FOL and other hydrogenation products in IPA at 30 ℃ under 1 MPa H2 pressure. The DPMF was formed through acetalization of FAL with two molecular of IPA and was identified by GC-MS (m/z, 198, 139, 97) [55,56]. The catalytic performance of Co/TiO2 was like that of pure TiO2, indicating the poor catalytic activity of Co alone in the Co/TiO2 sample having low Co loading. This is not surprising in view of the literature as discussed in the Introduction on the typical demand of high transition metal loading [21]. With monometallic Pt nanoparticles, both np-Pt/TiO2 and np-Pt/TiO2-g catalysts displayed relatively lower FAL conversions of 41% and 54%, with 72% and 63% FOL selectivity, respectively. The poor carbon balance was noted and was mainly due to the formation of byproduct-DPMF. Although the size of Pt particles (Fig. 3) in Pt/TiO2-g was much smaller than that in np-Pt/TiO2, the np-Pt/TiO2-g catalyst showed only marginally improved FAL conversion and FOL selectivity, suggesting that Pt particle size is not a dominating factor of an effective catalyst [25]. In comparison, a 99% FAL conversion with 97% selectivity to FOL was achieved on the bimetallic np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst under the same conditions despite the roughly similar Pt particle size distribution as the np-Pt/TiO2-g. It is worth noting that the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst displayed > 99.9% FAL conversion with > 99.9% FOL selectivity after adding 70 μl NaOH/IPA solution (1.7 g/L) into the reaction system. The complete conversion of FAL and no detectable by-product make the 0.5 wt% np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst particularly intriguing for potentially improved economic viability by reducing the cost of FOL separation and purification. Related, the use of IPA solvent is also preferable in view of FOL product recovery from this low boiling solvent by distillation, which allows the recovery and recycled use of the solvent at low energy consumption. The Arrhenius plots was used to calculated the apparent active energy (Ea) for FAL hydrogenation over monometallic np-Pt/TiO2 and bimetallic np-PtCo/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 6b) [57]. All the reaction rates were obtained at FAL conversion below 25%. The np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst has Ea of 23 kJ mol−1 which is significantly lower than that of the np-Pt/TiO2 catalyst at 31 kJ∙mol−1. In addition, the TOF value based on CO chemisorption is calculated to be as high as 14,023 h−1 for the np-PtCo/TiO2 under H2 pressure of 1 MPa at 30 ℃ for 10 min (28% FAL conversion with >99.9% FOL selectivity). It should be noticed that the mole of metal active sites was determined by CO chemisorption. According to the FT-IR results (Fig. 2b), both Pt and Co of bimetallic PtCo catalyst have CO adsorption peak, although the intensity of IR peak of CO on Pt is much stronger than that on Co. The calculated moles of metal active sites based on CO chemisorption therefore include both Pt and Co mole active sites. In comparison, the TOF value of np-Pt/TiO2 catalyst is 8249 h−1. It should be noted that CO chemisorption is used as a probe molecule to measure the surface metal atoms, it does not offer direct insight to the hydrogenation mechanism of a specific substrate. In the hydrogenation of furfural, the TOF provides a comparison on the efficiency of Pt metal. To conveniently compare the activity with other works, the specific reaction rates per molar Pt atoms are listed in Table 1 [13,29,58]. It is exciting to note that the highest reaction rate is achieved with our bimetallic np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst at the lowest Pt loading of 0.5%, even at a mild temperature of 30 ℃. The catalytic performance of bimetallic np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst with increasing reaction time from 1 to 5 h is shown in Fig. 6c. The conversion of FAL was increased until completion with time while the selectivity to FOL was maintained at > 99%. The most remarkable performance of the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst is the full mass balance in high selectivity to FOL product with no detectable by-product throughout the whole conversion range. The effect of temperature on FAL hydrogenation to FOL was studied by keeping the reaction time in 30 min (Fig. 6d). As the temperature was increased from 30 ℃ to 100 ℃, the conversion of FAL increased from 39% to 77% and the selectivity to FOL kept unchanged at > 99%. The results, therefore, show the highly stable performance of the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst by maintaining the high FOL selectivity even at high reaction temperature, indicating the active sites are stable and selective for FAL hydrogenation to FOL. Decreased catalytic selectivity to desired products could occur by enabling competing reaction pathways leading to by-product formation at elevated temperatures [30,58]. The effects of H2 pressure and support on FAL hydrogenation at 30 ℃ for 1 h are shown in Fig. S6. With increasing H2 pressure, the conversion of FAL (Fig. S6a) increased while the selectivity to FOL kept at > 99% all the time. The increased H2 pressure is expected to increase the H2 solubility in IPA solvent, and hence increasing the rate of the reaction [34]. The support also plays an important role in catalytic performance [60]. Compared to np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst, the np-PtCo/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. S6b) showed lower FAL conversion (29%) and the np-PtCo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst obtained only 4% FAL conversion. Although the activity of bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles decreased on SiO2 and γ-Al2O3, > 96% selectivity to FOL was still obtained under mild reaction conditions. The results further indicate that bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles are beneficial for selective hydrogenation of FAL to FOL. The Co/Pt molar ratio was also studied to optimize the component of bimetallic catalyst. As shown in Fig. S7, the conversions with Co/Pt molar ratios of 0.5, 1, 1.5 are 62%, 99.9% and 81%, respectively. The selectivities of these catalysts were all more than 90%. With increasing Co loading, the active sites may be increased, resulting an improved activity. However, in excessive Co loading, it may block the adsorption and dissociation of FAL and H2 molecule on Pt, resulting a decreased activity. 3.2.2 Selectivity-structure relationship and catalytic mechanism The FTIR spectroscopy was used to gain insight on the configuration of FAL adsorption on the surface of monometallic np-Pt/TiO2 and bimetallic np-PtCo/TiO2 catalysts ( Fig. 7), as the substrate adsorption configuration has a critical influence on catalyst activity and selectivity [61]. FAL was first added dropwise to the catalyst followed by washing using IPA solvent then dried at 30 ℃ (Fig. 7, curve a). For FAL adsorbed on monometallic Pt sample (Fig. 7a, curve a), the peaks at 1696, 1673 cm−1 are attributed to ν(CO) of physiosorbed FAL on the catalyst. The peak at 1635 cm−1 is ascribed to chemisorbed CO bond through O atom; the strong interaction between CO bond and Pt weakens the CO bond, resulting red-shift compared to the physiosorbed FAL wavenumber [60]. The peaks at 1570, 1474 and 1467 cm−1 belong to ν(CC) having strong IR absorption intensity, suggesting very weak adsorption of furan ring due to the electrostatic repulsion between electron-rich surface of Pt nanoparticles (Fig. 5a) and the delocalized electron in the aromatic furan ring [62]. After evacuation of the FAL-saturated Pt sample (Fig. 7a, curve b, c), the FTIR absorption intensity decreased as expected, with little change in the absorption wavenumbers. On the bimetallic PtCo catalyst (Fig. 7b, curve a), the most pronounced distinction in FAL adsorption from the monometallic Pt is observed by the intense sharp peak at 1499 cm−1 and a new peak at 1592 cm−1, while the absorption bands assigned to ν(CO) (1696, 1673 and 1635 cm−1) and ν(CC) (1570, 1474 and 1467 cm−1) are similar with that in the monometallic Pt sample. However, the peaks corresponding to CO (1696 and 1673 cm−1) and CC bonds of physiosorbed FAL molecules diminished significantly, while the peaks of chemisorbed species, especially at 1635 (CO), 1592 (CC), 1499 cm−1(CC), become dominating when the FAL-saturated bimetallic PtCo sample was evacuated (Fig. 7b, curve b, c). The results indicate that CO bond with O-terminal adsorption on Coδ+ of bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles is preferred; the lone pair electron of O can transfer to empty orbital of Coδ+ resulting a deeply polarized CO species of FAL, which becomes highly reactive. At the same time, the ν(CC) (1592 and 1499 cm−1) of furan ring becomes more like FOL (1594 and 1504 cm−1) due to the electron transfer [12]. The chemisorption of FAL molecule on monometallic Pt or bimetallic PtCo via CO bond makes FAL efficiently hydrogenated to FOL without hydrogenating the furan ring. What’s more, the CO bond with O-terminal adsorption on Coδ+ of bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles is much stronger than that on monometallic Pt nanoparticles, resulting in significantly weakened CO bond and remarkedly higher activity with bimetallic PtCo catalyst. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation was performed to rationalize the results of FT-IR with FAL adsorbed on the catalysts. The Pt (111) Plane of Pt and PtCo nanoparticles based on TEM were chosen to simplify the calculations. Fig. 8 shows the O-terminal of FAL molecular adsorption on both Pt (Fig. 7c) and PtCo (Fig. 7d) nanoparticles, with an adsorption energy (Ead) of − 0.22 and − 0.74 eV, respectively. The pronounced difference in Ead indicates that O atom in CO bond of FAL is favorably adsorbed on Coδ+ of bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles compared to its adsorption on Pt of monometallic Pt nanoparticles. The DFT results on CO adsorption energy are in excellent conformity to the FT-IR analysis. In addition to the ability of forming catalytically favorable FAL adsorption configuration on catalysts, the desorption of FOL product can also play important roles in FAL hydrogenation to FOL. Compared with the standard FOL data, the peaks at 1587, 1506 and 1498 cm−1 assigned to ν(CC) are observed in FT-IR spectra (Fig. S8) of FOL adsorbed on both monometallic Pt and bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles.12 However, the FT-IR absorption intensity of these FOL peaks is much lower than that of FAL, although it appears the intensity on PtCo is slightly weaker than that on Pt nanoparticles. The results suggest that FOL is hardly adsorbed on bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles. Consequently, FOL is expected to easily desorbed from PtCo surface. According to the adsorption analysis of FAL and FOL on the catalyst, the mechanism of bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles catalyzed FAL hydrogenation to FOL is proposed in Scheme 1. First, the CO group strongly adsorbs via O-terminal on Coδ+ of PtCo surface can be effectively polarized and activated due to the favorable electron transfer from O to Coδ+. The electron-rich states of Pt in PtCo nanoparticles could inhibit the interaction with the electron-rich furan ring (CC bond) by electrostatic repulsion, hence the furan ring hydrogenation by-product is limited [63]. At the same time, H2 adsorbed on Pt of PtCo nanoparticles is dissociated to active H that can readily migrate to the activated FAL to accomplish hydrogenation to FOL. Subsequently, the FOL rapidly desorbs from the catalyst surface, partially driven by the strong competitive adsorption of incoming FAL, and limiting FOL from over-hydrogenation to undesired by-products. In view of the easy dissociation of H2 molecular on Pt nanoparticles and effectively FOL desorption, the adsorption and activation of CO bond is proposed to be the rate determining step.[64] Thus, the monometallic Pt nanoparticles displayed lower activity than bimetallic PtCo nanoparticles, in consistent with the weaker chemisorption of FAL, and the results of FT-IR and DFT calculations. 3.2.3 Reusability of np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst The catalyst stability was tested by recycling of np-PtCo/TiO2 after recovering the catalyst from reaction mixture through filtration for the next run without further treatment. As shown in Fig. 8a, no visible decline in the catalytic activity and selectivity was observed for at least five cycles. The np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst remarkably maintained FAL conversion at about 73%, demonstrating that the catalyst is stable. To test the selectivity of FOL under close to full FAL conversion in catalyst reuses, we also chose to test another batch of catalyst for 5 h, at which full conversion of FAL was reached according to Fig. 6c, to verify the stability and the sustained high selectivity of np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8b, excellent stability and selectivity to FOL were maintained even under full FAL conversion. Consistent with the results of catalytic stability tests, the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst after fifth recycle didn't show obvious agglomeration of PtCo nanoparticles (Fig. 4f), with mean particles size at 2.7 nm (Fig. 4g) and the Co is still distributed along the Pt nanoparticles (Fig. 4h). In addition, the molar ratio of Co/Pt determined by ICP-OES remained 0.7, the same as that of the fresh np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst, confirming the compositional stability of bimetallic np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst in the reaction mixture. 4 Conclusion Using a pre-made stock solution of zero valent atomic Pt and Co2(CO)8, we demonstrate an effective methodology for the synthesis of supported bimetallic PtCo catalysts. The presence of Co is found to offer at least three prominent functions in the preparation and the catalytic performance of the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst: (1) stabilizing bimetal PtCo nanoparticles in a narrow size distribution centered at 2.8 nm, possibly by decorating the unsaturated Pt sites during the agglomeration process under H2 pressure, (2) maintaining stable np-PtCo structure and composition under reaction conditions, and (3) most importantly, deeply polarizing the CO bond by strong oxyphilic interaction with O of -CO group of FAL. This strong interaction between -CO and Coδ+ on the surface of PtCo nanoparticles not only selectively activates the -CO responsible for largely reduced activation energy, but also effectively promotes the desorption of FOL. Consequently, the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst achieved > 99.9% selectivity to FOL at complete conversion of FAL under mild conditions (30 ℃, 1 MPa H2). Most importantly in the development of highly efficient catalyst with low metal loading as economically competitive alternative process, we demonstrate that only 0.5 wt% loading of Pt in the np-PtCo/TiO2 (Co/Pt molar ratio of 0.7) catalyst, to the best of our knowledge, exhibited significantly superior catalytic performance (TOF to 14,023 h−1 and specific reaction rate of 1683 h−1) even under milder reaction conditions compared to reported catalysts with high Pt metal content. Furthermore, the catalytic stability is verified by its steadily maintained performance in two sets of cycled uses, one at ~73% FAL conversion and another at 100% FAL conversion, without obvious changes in particle size distribution and in metal composition. The high selectivity in hydrogenation of -CO group and the excellent stability of the supported np-PtCo catalyst achieved even in very low metal loading and under mild conditions make this type of catalysts potentially promising for broadly selective carbonyl hydrogenations, especially for the conversions of a wide range of biobased chemicals. This work also offers a new insight into designing well shaped and high-efficiency functional bimetallic catalysts with low noble metal contents using the atomic precursor. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenation of carbonyl groups in biobased chemicals to alcohols is crucial to the economics of broadly sustainable product portfolios. Furfuryl alcohol (FOL), the most prominent chemical of hemicellulose, has been produced by furfural (FAL) hydrogenation over heterogeneous catalysts. In this work, we show the outstanding activity, selectivity, and stability of supported bimetallic PtCo nanoparticle (np) synthesized from a pre-made stock solution of zero valent atomic Pt precursor and Co2(CO)8. With only 0.5 wt% Pt on TiO2, the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst exhibits TOF of 14,023 h−1 at 30 °C with > 99.9% FOL selectivity. The stability of the np-PtCo/TiO2 catalyst is verified by the steady performance in reuses at both moderate and full conversions. The oxyphilic Coδ+ in the PtCo nanoparticles induces nucleophilic chemisorption of -CO, resulting in deeply polarized CO bond. DFT calculated FAL adsorption energies on np-Pt and np-PtCo are − 0.22 eV and − 0.74 eV, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: Co decorated low Pt loading nanoparticles over TiO2 catalyst for selective hydrogenation of furfural
